right so uh kubernetes is fundamentally an apid driven system so at the center of our universe is this thing we call
the API server and it is a uh a rest server so it's a you know web server
with uh rest semantics and uh we talk in terms of rest resources or or objects uh
and those objects describe the various bits of semantics of our system those are things like pods and services and uh
end points and load balancers and those sorts of things each machine within your cluster has an agent that runs that
machine and that machine is that that agent is called the cuet uh following in the vein of Borg which had its borlet
and Omega which had its omelet uh so the the cuit uh runs on every machine and it
is responsible for talking to the API server figuring out what that machine is supposed to be doing uh you know which
containers is it supposed to run um and then activating those changes the API
server runs on what we tend to call the master um it doesn't have to be a single machine or a of machines dedicated to
this but it's the most common way that people operate so on the master are some other components that run alongside it
one is the scheduler um the scheduler is just a uh consumer of our API so
everything we do consumes our API there are no uh back channels there are no secret apis um you know everything uses
the public API so the scheduler looks at the public API and it says hey is there
work in here that hasn't been assigned to a worker if there is I'll go do that assign assignment and that's basically
all it does uh and then we have this thing called the controller manager uh which implements a control pattern that
we call controllers and what a controller does is it says like I have a job my job is to make sure that a load
balancer exists for this service and that's all I do and I watch the API
server and I wait for changes and when things change I wake up I activate whatever the thing that I was asked to
change uh and then I go back to sleep and periodically I'm going to wake up and I'm just going to check the state of the universe and make sure that it
exists in the form that I expect it to exist and if it doesn't I'm going to drive towards the uh declared State this
is the sort of declarative model and uh so the controller manager implements all
of the most common controllers that we have for our system these are things like resolving uh end points for
services or managing nodes making sure that nodes are healthy and doing health checks there making sure that uh I mean
the Schuler itself is a controller um and so all of these pieces wake up and they're always talking to the API
server constantly so if you were to watch the API serers uh logs you'll see that it's constantly busy just answering
these requests for get these objects put these objects update this patch that when you use our command line tool Cube
cuddle uh it does the exact same thing it talks to the API server it gets
